title: How to Plant a Living Christmas Tree
original_title: How to Grow Your Own Christmas Tree
content: are you tired of facing struggle over Christmas tree shopping or you are just tired of artificial trees every year it may be time to consider growing your own Christmas trees here are some easy steps to grow your own Christmas tree step 1 choosing your tree firs firs our popular Christmas trees they have a fragrant scent beautiful colors and ability to retain their needles they are best suited for colder or elevated regions harvesting time 9 to 10 years some best types of firs are Fraser Fir Douglas fir concolor fir balsam fir noble fir pines pines are quick growing and will reach a viable height of 6 to 7 feet in six years given optimal growing conditions harvesting time six years some vest types of pines are white pine Virginia pine Scotch pine sand pine spruces spruce trees are bright and colorful but they have prickly needles and tend to lose their needles after a week or two harvesting time nine to ten years some best types of spruces are Norway spruce Colorado blue spruce cypresses and Cedars cypresses and Cedars require relatively little shaping and the leland cypresses can reach six to seven feet in a relatively short amount of time harvesting time for years some best types of them are Leyland cypress Arizona Cyprus Eastern redcedar step to grow the seedling you will need to plant the seedling in a potting mixture in a pot the potting mixture should be made of equal parts peat vermiculite and perlite you will also need a fluorescent lamp to heat the seeds step 3 getting planting site ready make sure the planting site has a slope having a planting site with a 5% to 20% slope will ensure there is good water drainage and good air for growth you should also ensure the site gets full Sun step 4 mow the area before planting prepare the soil for the seedling by removing any existing vegetation with a mower step 5 planting the tree dig a hole that is the same depth as the hole the seedling was grown in at the nursery or in the greenhouse place the seedling in the hole and spread the roots carefully and gently if you are planting more than one transplant seedling at a time make sure the trees are planted in rows eight feet apart with seven to eight feet between each seedling step 6 cultivation water the tree during the dry months or during a drought maintain the planting sites so there are no weeds or grasses prune and cheer the tree when the needles are long it is important to give tree a desired shape step 7 harvesting harvest the tree within six to nine years you can harvest the tree by cutting it down with a chain saw or a handsaw cut the tree down during the late fall you should cut the tree when it is full of moisture usually during the late fall so the needles stay green and supple when the tree is displayed indoors step 8 preservation place the tree in a container with water as soon as it is cut if the country seals the tree will not be able to take in water and may not have a very long lifespan step 9 decoration there you have your own Christmas tree decorate it with different items I will help you with my other video

title: How to Plant a Living Christmas Tree
original_title: How to Set Up an Artificial Christmas Tree
content: hi my name is bill Quinn with Christmas tree for me an artificial Christmas tree is a convenient and beautiful way to bring the Christmas season into your home I'd like to show you how to set up your artificial Christmas tree but first make sure that you have a good pair of gloves and a long-sleeve shirt as the Christmas tree will have little pieces of plastic that can give you paper cuts the most important thing is to make sure that the stand is stable you'll want to take the stand and set it up on a table and make sure that all four feet are firmly touching the top of the table this will ensure that the tree has stability when you set it up on your floor and put all the sections on it the size of the tree will determine how many sections the tree will have the tree that we're using today has four sections we'll take the bottom section of the tree which is going to have the tapered into it and we'll put that into the stand then we will go through and fluff the tree we want to start from the center of the tree and work our way out and then we'll plug the tree into the wall we want to go around and check to make sure that all the lights are working properly once we've done that we'll want to move to the next section and when we put on the next section we want to take a bar of soap and put a light coat between the two connections this will ensure that the two sections will come apart after Christmas we'll plug in that section into the next section below we'll check the lights and we'll fluff the tree and you'll repeat that for the remaining two sections once you have all of the sections set up then what you want to do is take a step back from the tree and look for any holes or gaps you can fill those holes or gaps by gently bending branches over the gap now that your tree is set up all you need is a few ornaments and a few presents and you'll be ready to enjoy the season with your family to watch the other segments in this video series or for how-to videos on almost any other topic visit monkey-see calm

title: How to Plant a Living Christmas Tree
original_title: How to Keep a Potted Christmas Tree Alive
content: how to keep a potted Christmas tree alive potted Christmas trees are biodegradable and can be recycled into mulch or help reduce erosion living trees can also be used for several holiday seasons before you must purchase a new one when you purchase a potted Christmas tree in the winter it is an ax dormant state where it remains inactive until the spring weather arrives it can lose its needles turn brown in color and eventually die if you disrupt the dormancy so keep your Christmas tree attractive by caring for it properly things you will need anti transparent spray saw spray the Christmas tree needles with an anti transparent straight to keep the moisture in the needles slice 1/2 inch off the bottom of the tree trunk with a saw before you place it in a pot this allows the tree to absorb water so it stays fresh if you purchase a tree already in a pot soak the root ball in one to two inches of warm water for approximately 1 hour keep the tree outdoors in a shaded location away from the direct sunlight and wind until you are ready to bring it indoors you can also store it in the garage if the weather becomes too cold so the root bulb does not freeze store the Christmas tree in your home for no longer than 7 days the tree must remain in dormancy and the warm temperatures will affect the health of the plant water the soil to keep it damp if you do not have soil in the pot keep the tree stand full to the level of the tree base inspect the water level or soil dampness daily find a location in your home away from direct heat and air ducts the heat causes the tree to lose its moisture quickly string lights on the Christmas tree that release little heat turn the lights off when you do not use them to help keep the tree dormant [Music]

title: How to Plant a Living Christmas Tree
original_title: How to Safely Put Up a Real, Live Christmas Tree
content: how to safely put up a real live Christmas tree make sure this year's live holiday tree is not only pretty but safe too you will need a fresh tree a tree stand water a ceiling hook a piece of wire tree lights and blue masking tape optional LED tree lights and a heavy gauge extension cord step 1 choose a tree with fresh green needles that don't easily fall off when you shake the trunk or run your fingers over a branch the drier the tree the bigger the fire hazard needles should bend but not break and the trunk should feel sticky with SAP step 2 ask the tree vendor to cut 2 or 3 inches off the bottom so your tree will better absorb water from its stand step 3 choose a spot for the tree at least 3 feet from a radiator fireplace heating vent or other heat source and don't block any exits with it never light candles near the tree step 4 put the tree into a tree stand filled with fresh water as soon as you bring it home and keep it watered don't skimp on the tree stand use a sturdy one that will keep your tree straight step 5 with a piece of wire attach the top of the tree to a hook in the ceiling so it can't tip over step 6 use tree lights made for indoor use check for damaged sockets missing bulbs and frayed wires before hanging them on the tree that are upgrading to LED lights available where other tree lights are sold you'll spend a bit more but they're safer because they don't generate heat step 7 tape down any loose cord so people don't trip over them use blue masking tape to prevent paint damage never run cords under rugs it's a fire hazard and don't attach more than three light strands to an extension cord use heavy gauge extension cords they stay cool and don't fray easily step 8 if you have young children or pets keep breakable ornaments out of their reach step 9 when the tree starts losing needles take it to a recycling center dried out trees account for hundreds of fires each year during the holidays did you know Benjamin Harrison was the first president to display an official White House Christmas tree [Music]

content: hoods tree farm has been around for many years providing Christmas trees to malboro residents so whose tree farm has been around over I would say 60 years my grandfather started selling Christmas trees at his house he purchased this property that you see in 1976 and started growing Christmas trees casteau explains why customers still come to cut down their own tree rather than buying a fake one it's a special kind of thing cutting down your own Christmas trees so those kind of people aren't going to put up a fake tree so it doesn't seem to affect our business hoods offers quite a variety of different trees we have pines spruces and firs we have white pines and Scotch pines we also sell some native scrub Pines we have white spruce blue spruce Norway spruce Frasier fir balsam fir concolor fir and Douglas fir every customer has a different tastes different people like a different type of tree so in New England the the classic tree is a balsam Fraser is very similar to balsam growing a Christmas tree is a process some take 10 or even 15 years to be fully grown the trees laid out in rows so in the flat areas there's a tree every five feet and we do that so we can get through with a mower and trim around them you dig a small hole to plant the seedling and then you close the hole around the roots of the seedling and essentially we don't fertilize unless we need to some people just come to walk around the farm and take in the holiday experience this is a 37 acre parcel of land and people love just to come here and walk even if they don't cut a tree down they usually get a pre-cut but they love the experience of seeing Santa getting some hot cocoa a candy cane and sharing it with their family for more information on hoods tree farm visit hood tree farm com

title: How to Plant a Living Christmas Tree
original_title: How to Plant a Tree
content: how to plant a tree trees ask for little mostly because they cannot talk so just assume that they like company and plant them a new friend you will need a site for your tree a trowel a soil sample a list of tree species native to your area a local nursery that sells native trees a large shovel fertilizer mulch and a hose or other water supply optional supports and protection for the tree and compost step 1 choose a spot to plant your new sapling step 2 dig a small sample of the soil and take a look if it is heavy with clay or very sandy please add one part compost to every three parts oil that you shovel out step 3 check for wires and pipes above and below your site if there are wires above you may still be able to plant a low growing tree step 4 this is a local nursery and pick out a sapling ideally one five to six feet tall match the trees preferred soil type and sun exposure to the site you have chosen trees that are native to your area are more likely to do well in your ecosystem and provide food and habitat to wildlife step 5 dig a hole no higher than the root ball but at least twice as wide we have rough surfaces in the hole so roots can penetrate as they grow Rutan the sides and the bottom of the hole with a stick or shovel step 6 quickly remove the root ball from its container and gently straighten the roots as needed if the roots are wrapped in burlap let it fall to the bottom of the hole step 7 place the tree in the hole then stand back to see if it is straight adjust as needed step 8 replace soil around the roots the flare where the roots spread at the trees base should be just above the soil line step 9 pack the soil around the tree firmly but gently with hands and feet to fill in any air pockets but not so hard that water can't get in step 10 spread mulch two inches deep at a ring about two feet in diameter around the tree but not within a few inches of the Trump mulch can be woodchips pine needles grass clippings or fallen leaves the ideal time to plant a deciduous tree is well at dormant in fall after leaves dropped or an early spring before leaves come out step 11 water your tree when it does rain a young tree will need to be watered about every week for the first year step 12 protect your tree from strong winds by tying two stakes to the trunk if you have deer in the area wrap the trunk loosely with wire mesh hardware cloth especially in winter did you know in the summer an acre of Iowa forest can call the surrounding area by as much as 15 degrees

content: want to plant a great tree in your yard here's what to do to give it a great start the first thing to think about is where to plant your tree some zoning and neighborhood associations have rules about what and where you can and can't plant also before you dig call 811 to have any underground utilities marked watch the space to see how much sun it gets that'll be important when you select your tree all the trees at the garden center have tags that specify things like sun or shade locations they'll also tell you the size of the mature tree so you know how far to plant from buildings fences landscaping or overhead wires the tags also have info about the right growing zone for each tree those plants are selected for the climate in your area native trees are best a good time to plant is in the fall or early spring in southern areas trees can be planted in winter once you have your trees and location it's time to plant dig the hole about two times the width and the exact depth of the container loosen the soil at the bottom and sides of the hole double check that the hole is deep enough by temporarily placing the tree pull the tree out and add some water to the hole to moisten the soil at the bottom then remove the container by cutting it on two sides hold the tree by the root ball and place it in the hole gently loosen the roots to help them grow out make sure that the trunk is straight and the top of the root crown is even with the ground now backfill the hole with soil filling all around the roots gently tamp the soil to remove any air pockets add about two inches of mulch on the dug up area this will help hold moisture and protect the roots in cold climates finally you need to thoroughly soak the soil with water for the first year you should water two to three times a week and even more in dry weather a timer and a soaker hose can make that job easier with that your tree is ready to grow healthy and strong want more great ideas and how to's go to lowes.com how to or just click to subscribe next learn how to plant bulbs
